Award.AwardTitle: William & Mary Women In Scientific Education (WISE) Initiative

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The College of William and Mary is proposing a host of activities to advance women in academic STEM at their own institution as well as two nearby institutions, Richard Bland College and Thomas Nelson Community College. The project has three primary goals and a variety of initiatives to accomplish their goals. The main goal involves career development and mentoring. Initiatives surrounding this goal include an ambitious slate of workshops to promote scholarly writing and professional development. Also a leadership forum and a visiting female scientist program will be initiated. Organic mentoring will be encouraged through one-day annual retreats for all STEM female faculty across the three campuses. The project also includes a variety of research grant opportunities for the STEM women across the campuses. The second goal of the proposal combines efforts to evaluate the effectiveness of the programming described above with research based in the social science literature surrounding the reduction of implicit gender bias. The third goal of the proposal is to increase inter-institutional collaborations among the three participating institutions.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT
This proposal is well written and developed. The initiatives focused on promoting the research agendas of the STEM women are particularly strong and well suited to the needs of less research-intensive institutions. The social science research component of the proposal is very well grounded in the literature and represents a robust, real-life test of possible mechanisms to change implicit bias. The PIs have taken some of the strongest and most successful ADVANCE programming and adapted it appropriately to their context.

BROADER IMPACTS

The collaborative nature of the programming presents a nice opportunity for broader impacts by including STEM faculty at two primarily undergraduate institutions and a community college. The three campuses have over 100 STEM, women, full-time faculty. The social science research is positioned to contribute importantly to the scientific literature on the reduction of implicit bias. The success of these programs, combined with empirical support for a reduction in implicit bias can lead to a replicable model among similar institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF-funded ADVANCE PAID award #1107147, entitled Women In Scientific Education (WISE), was an initiative based at The College of William & Mary. It additionally served two nearby schools (Richard Bland College -RBC and Thomas Nelson Community College- TNCC). WISE was dedicated to the advancement of women in the STEM disciplines, including the behavioral sciences, at the assistant professor and associate professor rank.

To this end, there were three core areas of impact. First, there were development and mentoring activities through lecture series and an annual retreat, grant and manuscript writing workshops, and an availability of travel awards and research grants for summer, equipment, and seed funding. Second, we completed research and climate studies to assess and education our faculty of self/other perception of women in science and expectations for career advancement using in-group/out-group experimental paradigms based on the Implicit Association Test (IAT) for Gender-Science is planned. Third, through inter-institutional collaboration, WISE aimed to improve faculty relations and the increase collaboration between women in the STEM disciplines at William & Mary and the Richard Bland and Thomas Nelson. Specifically, it was our aim to build on existing relationships across these schools in order to create a supportive and collaborative atmosphere committed to the presence and advancement of WISE- based activities in our region.

Because William & Mary, Richard Bland, and Thomas Nelson are smaller, state schools that focus on undergraduate curriculum in the Arts & Sciences, we sought to build on their unique environments for women faculty and students in STEM careers. For our own purposes, we adapted activities from projects previously funded by the NSF ADVANCE program. In particular, topics of focus on the Virginia Tech Portal, activities at the University of Washington ADVANCE Center for Institutional Change, inter-institutional partnering in the Skidmore-Union College/SUN Network, and use of the IAT in the University of Northern Colorado’s CCAS Initiative were adapted for the proposed WISE activities. The resulting structure of our activities was based on evidence of best practices at other institutions when matched for activity kind, scope, focus, or school type. 

During the tenure of the award, we were able to impact over 100 research projects, most of which enabled women investigators to collect data that they could then use in applications for larger, federally funded and private awards. Moreover, there were a large number of travel awards that provided means to attend conferences that would have otherwise been impossible, especially for the community college faculty who have no access to funds. 

Most importantly, we were able to form a community of women scientists across three regional campuses (WM, TNCC, and RBC), we fostered collaboration across the campuses, and we empowered women to work independently and as teams to help maximize their capabilities. Our annual retreat is a great example of the group having an opportunity to talk with and learn from each other, especially from more senior women in the academy. Listening to the shared stories from our speakers allowed the group to consider personal but also common obstacles and the retreat in general provided a forum for sharing and support with the goal of identifying routes to success.

WISE was certainly a civic-minded, rather than PI research centered, funding award. I am grateful to have had the opportunity to work on something much larger than myself, to increase the visibility of women on our campuses, and to be a part of a federally-funded initiative developed to meet the needs to women faculty. It was a honor and pleasure to work on the WISE grant.
